content: Hi Titasgirl  Yes, we posted at the same time (1 min), lol.  About your concerns on the size of the “mass”. Mainly. there are two ways to evaluate if a lung lesion has grown: one is determining its growth rate by comparing its size on a current image with that on prior images, using the maximum diameter; the other is to judge against volumes. On September the diameter was 2.5 cms, and on the last report it was 1.9 x 4.5 cms, being 4.5 the largest. Anyway, I was not talking about that particular value, the radiologist reported more lung lesions that where larger than previous ones:  FINDINGS: Again noted is an ill defined right apical pleural-based mass with adjacent pleural thickening. Pleural mass measures approximately 1.9 x 4.5 cm, (back in September was 2.5 cm) not significantly changed. Extensive underlying pulmonary emphysematous changes are noted. Multiple small bilateral pulmonary nodules are present. 2 right lower lobe nodules are increased in size with the largest measuring 1.3 x 0.7. Punctuate left lower lobe nodule appears new. Mediastinal and right hilar Lymphadenopathy is not significant changed with subcarinal node measuring 4.4 x 2.7 cm. The right effusion is increased.   IMPRESSION: 1. Right upper lobe pleural based mass likely representing primary bronchogenic neoplasm. This is amenable to CT guided biopsy. 2. Mediastinal Lymphadenopathy without significant interval change. 3. Additional pulmonary nodules concerning for metastatic disease. Several are increased in size.  About explaining what are "unmistakably characteristics of benignity". There are some highly reliable findings of benignity on CT scans, like degree of enhancement of the lesion, type of margins and contours, and other internal characteristics, like presence of fat inside the lesion, some patterns of calcification inside the tumor (central calcification in benign tumors), etc.  Hope you find the information useful.  Good luck,  Dr Torax

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Titasgirl,  I’m really sorry to hear they confirmed it is lung cancer.  About the stages of lung cancer, if the pleural fluid shows malignant cells it is IIIB, but if a pleural biopsy is positive it is stage IV. Also, if the CT shows other lung tumors, even if they are small, it is also classified as stage IV disease.  Patients with stage IIIB or IV do not benefit from surgery and are best managed by chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or a combination of both, depending on the sites of tumor involvement, and most important, on the patient’s performance status (general health condition). That’s because, even though there can be many treatment alternatives, the patient may not be able to tolerate them. Patients with excellent performance status can have combined therapy; however, patients with malignant pleural effusion are not always candidates for radiotherapy and usually are treated like stage IV patients, with chemotherapy.  Currently, in patients with inoperable stage IIIB or IV disease, specialists recommend as first-line chemotherapy (initial drug preference) a combined drug regimen (platinum-based or not). For patients with adequate performance status who have failed on first-line, platinum-based therapy, Docetaxel (brand name: Taxotere), is recommended as second-line therapy.  Unfortunately, treatment with those kinds of drugs may be contraindicated in elderly patients because of age-related impairment of organ functions and/or the presence of other diseases. Doctors must evaluate performance status and other illness co-existence rather than age when choosing treatment options for elderly patients.  Erlotinib (brand name:Tarceva) is recommended for the treatment of patients after failure of both platinum-based and docetaxel chemotherapies. This drug has a different mechanism for stopping cancer cells from growing and multiplying than those of chemotherapy and hormonal therapy. Erlotinib may stop the growth of tumor cells by blocking some of the enzymes needed for cell growth.  Because elderly patients with advanced lung cancer typically have few treatment options, investigators carried out clinical trials using Erlotinib as single therapy in elderly patients without prior chemotherapy; studies demonstrated tumor shrinkage good enough to help restore quality of life so that patients can carry on recreational activities. Other benefit of the drug is it can be taken once a day by mouth.  Age itself should not preclude an elderly patient from receiving chemotherapy. Currently, single-agent chemotherapy and nonplatinum or platinum-based doublets can all be considered as appropriate treatment for elderly patients with good performance status. Doctor’s judiciousness, drug toxicity profiles, presence of other diseases, and patient preferences are fundamental to decide on which drug to use.  If your grandmother’s health condition isn’t good enough to tolerate regular chemotherapy regimens, Tarceva is a good choice.  I wish luck to you and your grandmother,  Dr. Alberto de la Guerra

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Elo*,  I totally agree with Angela, although you have a smoking history, at your age, the probability of lung cancer is extremely remote, and rarely, cancer involving the chest or cancer that has spread from another part of the body can cause chest pain. Even more, when lung cancer causes pain it reveals an advanced stage of the tumor, and should be accompanied with other signs and symptoms. Thus, if the doctor said your lungs are clear and you don’t have other complains, I think you don’t have to worry about it. But if you continue smoking, in the near future you may be concern not only about lung cancer, but on cancer of the mouth, lips, throat, esophagus, stomach, anus, kidney, bladder, liver, pancreas, and leukemia, among others (tobacco smoke is responsible of at least 30% of all cancers).  As Angela pointed out, the chest pain you are experiencing could be related to the smoking, but if you are not a heavy smoker, your chest pain might have other origin.  Chest pain has a lot of causes, and they fall into two major categories: cardiac and non-cardiac causes. In young adults, without a history of previous cardiac illness, a non-cardiac problem is likely to be the origin of the pain. In this category the more frequent causes are musculoskeletal problems, gastrointestinal diseases (usually stomach acid reflux causing heartburn), and panic attacks, a form of anxiety (unexpected fear accompanied by chest pain, fast heartbeat, rapid breathing, sweating and shortness of breath).  In young healthy people, chest pain usually is caused by musculoskeletal problems of the chest wall (ribs, sternum, articulations, and muscles). The middle chest bone is the sternum, also called breastbone. The sternum articulates with the ribs 1 through 7 on either sides of the chest. When chest pain is felt along the edges of the breastbone, and appears when you take particular positions or make some movements, and is not related to exercise or gets worse with it, the most probable causes are costochondritis, Tietze’s syndrome, and benign chest wall pain.   Costochondritis is an inflammation of the cartilage that connects a rib to the breastbone, and is the most common cause of chest pain originating in the chest wall. Costochondritis causes your chest to hurt when you push on your sternum or on the ribs near your sternum. Most commonly the cause of costochondritis is classified as 'idiopathic,' or unknown. This means that there is no identifiable cause for the condition. Frequently costochondritis and Tietze’s syndrome are mistaken as being the same disease. Costochondritis typically presents with pain around the second to fifth costochondral joints, without swelling of the affected zone; in Tietze's syndrome there is swelling and pain of the articulation.   Benign chest wall pain is a transient and brief irritation of the pleura, the membrane that lines the lungs, and is very sensitive to pain. For unexplained causes, its transitory irritation can be a severe painful sensation. This condition has no medical significance at all.  The pain caused by these conditions usually improves within a few weeks. While some pain may persist, it is usually mild and only associated with some body positions or movements. All symptoms of pain should resolve within six months. If the pain gets worse or persists for a long time you should seek for medical attention.  Hope you find this information useful.  Sincerely,  Alberto de la Guerra.

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Karen, Merry Christmas,  Sorry I couldn’t reply earlier. I think that your husband made the right choice with the phase II trial. About liver function tests and dangerous levels, it’s a complex question to answer.  First of all, the commonly used liver function tests primarily assess liver damage rather than hepatic function. Indeed, these blood tests may reflect problems arising outside the liver, like bone disease (elevated alkaline phosphatase level). Abnormal values often, but not always, indicate something wrong in the liver, and provide clues to the nature of the problem. However, normal values do not always mean that the liver is normal. Of the routine liver function tests, only serum albumin, bilirubin and prothrombin time provide useful information on how well the liver is functioning.  I can give you the normal adult male ranges, but I don’t think it’s going to be of much help. Interpretation of liver function tests is a sophisticated process that physicians make use of in the context of a medical history, physical examination, and other tests such as X-rays or other imaging studies of the liver.  Laboratory analysis are ancillary tests, their values, single-handed, are not useful to estimate the severity of liver illness. Doctors must be aware that values can be higher or lower depending on patient’s nourishment status and vitamin levels, previous diseases, medication intake, hormones levels, etc. Also, values are not linear numbers; an AST that is 300 is not twice as bad as 150 (normal is less than 40), and an AST of 94 and 80 are essentially the same to a liver specialist. Moreover, normal ranges may fluctuate somewhat according to the brand of laboratory assay materials used. In conclusion, these tests have a meaning, but they generally cannot be interpreted without clinical information.  I feel you must let the doctors take care of the liver tests. Although, there are some signs you can be aware of, which are related to liver impairment, like jaundice (yellow color in the skin, mucous membranes, or eyes), confusion, abdominal growth (due to ascites, an abnormal accumulation of fluids inside the belly), swelling of the feet and ankles, and abnormal bleeding. More reliable than lab tests is how is your husband feeling right now.  Hope you find this information helpful.  Best regards,  Dr Torax

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Karen,   I read your husband’s brief history, and I think he’s been properly treated. I’m going to give you an overview of current treatment options for lung cancer recurrence and liver metastases.  When lung cancer recurs (appears again) we need to evaluate some issues to select the proper treatment: like previous therapy (surgery, chemo, etc), site - number - size of new tumors, and most important the patient’s general health status. This is important because, although there can be multiple treatment options, the patient may not be able to tolerate them. I guess your husband has good enough strength since he is ongoing second line chemotherapy.  Regarding your question about what to try next to stop progression, it’s hard to tell. Unfortunately at this time there’s no evidence supporting which treatment (second-line chemo) is more effective to control disease progression; besides, prolonging chemotherapy beyond 4 cycles does not get better results.  About liver mets treatment options, I don’t think liver cancer drugs are a good alternative, among other reasons, because chemotherapy cannot cure liver cancer.  In some cases, where the liver is the only site of recurrence, there are some treatment alternatives, others than surgical resection or chemotherapy. Currently there are 5 minimally invasive techniques for the treatment of secondary malignant hepatic tumors: tumors radio-frequency ablation, microwave ablation, laser ablation, cryoablation, and chemoembolization. As well, some requisites have to be fulfill previously.  For example, treatment with radio-frequency ablation is feasible when there are 4 or fewer liver tumors, 5-cm or smaller and no extrahepatic tumor. Ideal tumors are smaller than 3 cm in diameter and 2 cm or more away from large hepatic vessels. Based on review of the CT scan, the doctor will decide if it is the appropriate treatment.  My advice is to wait for the scan results, then, if needed, ask the doctors about other treatment options. Also consider the possibility of clinical trials. Have no doubts that your husband is getting the best treatment currently available in one of the top cancer centers worlwide.  I wish the best for you and your husband.  Sincerely, Dr_Torax.

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Karen,  Unfortunately, based on current scientific evidence, I cannot tell you if reducing the tumor’s burden will slow down the progression in his liver. There have not been many reports of liver metastasectomy after treatment for lung cancer. Reports published before 1988 did not consider that resection of metastases was worthwhile. More recent reports have been more favorable and this reflects the improvements in liver surgery that have since taken place.  There are guidelines as to which patients can have surgery for liver metastases. In general patients should have 5 or less separate metastatic sites to the liver. These need to be localized in one area such that they can be removed. A functional portion of the liver will need to remain, approximately 2/3rds of the liver can be resected and due to the liver's regenerative capacity a patient with a normal liver prior to surgery can do quite well.  Surgery for metastatic disease to the liver is not indicated when there are multiple tumors or extrahepatic disease is present, because to achieve control of disease progression we need to get rid of all the tumors. Chemotherapy is the best treatment option in those cases, or if disease is stable and there are no symptoms, maybe just follow-up and take care of the problems as they appear.  I wish the best for you and your husband.  Sincerely, Dr_Torax.

content: Hello Sam9, About your first question, CT scan is the best non-invasive diagnostic test to rule out lung cancer in a symptomatic patient (screening is looking for cancer before a person has any symptoms). About screening, The U.S. Preventive Services Task Force concludes that the evidence is insufficient to recommend for or against screening asymptomatic persons for lung cancer. At this time we are waiting for the National Lung Screening Trial conclusions to see which test is better for early detection (screening) of lung cancer. I don’t think you have to worry about lung cancer, because usually symptoms appear when the disease is in an advanced stage (lung tumor or metastases are present), and the CT didn’t find a lung tumor or thoracic lymph node. About lymphoma, the most common finding is a swollen lymph node; others include decreased numbers of blood cells (red blood cells, white blood cells and platelets), fevers, night sweats and weight loss. In a patient with symptoms a chest CT scan can detect disease inside the thorax. Infrequently a CT scan detects a lymphoma in absence of symptoms or other findings.  Regarding you second question, there are a number of tests available to diagnose a heart disease, like electrocardiogram, CXR, blood tests, stress tests, echocardiogram and cardiac catheterization. According to the recommendations of the American College of Cardiology Foundation and the American Heart Association, the standard workout to diagnose an ischemic heart disease includes EKG, 2D echo, stress test, and blood test. However, they still consider the patient’s history and physical examination the most important part of the evaluation. So if your doctor didn’t find out anything wrong, and your tests came out normal, you don’t need to be concerned. The most common symptom of pulmonary hypertension, and virtually everyone who has the condition develops it, is shortness of breath upon exertion. Based on the symptoms, a doctor may suspect pulmonary hypertension in people who have an underlying lung disorder. To diagnose pulmonary hypertension doctors may order pulmonary function tests and all the others I mentioned for cardiac diseases. Definite diagnosis may require cardiac catheterization.  I hope you find the information helpful.

title: Tarceva - small cell lung cancer
content: Tarceva (erlotinib) was recently approved by the FDA as a therapy for non-small cell lung cancer, but is not approved for small cell lung cancer. There are a variety of options for small cell patients, depending on the "stage" of the disease. Knowing more about the history, diagnosis date, clinical findings, etc., would be helpful in offering you further suggestions.  The most important thing to remember is that your own oncologist is your best resource. You should never hesitate to ask her or him any question whatsoever. If you do not understand the answer, ask your doctor to take a moment to further explain matters until you have a good grasp of what you're being told.   Best wishes for your success in treatment!

title: Lung nodule, plus liver and spleen
content: This is a great forum, thank you to all the doctors and nurses who give their time.  Ok.  I am a 30 year old female, non-smoker.  I had been having a pain in my right side around my waist so I saw my doctor, who drew blood and took a urine sample.  Actually she only took the urine because I thought she'd want it and I filled the cup just in case.  Turned out I had a kidney infection and a fever, blood was normal so I got antibiotics and was sent on my merry way.  A month later and I still have the pain.  She re-examined me (I'd also had a normal gyno exam in the meantime) and ordered a CT scan.  I got the results today because I called and asked about it, and was told that they didn't find anything that would cause me pain.  It was mostly normal but they found a nodule in my left lung, one on my liver and one on my spleen.  They want me to have another CT in six months to see if they've changed.  Other than that, that's all the info I got from them.  I'm nervous because you can't search on "nodule" without finding cancer.  I would like to think that they would have called me right away and ordered more tests sooner if they felt it was something to worry about, but is a "wait and see" approach appropriate at this time?  Other than the side pain (I'm starting to examine my diet for clues on that), I have had no problems and feel great.  My doctor just called and said I have nothing to worry about since I'm young and healthy.  She said that most people have little things like this come up in a scan and that they're just imperfections like a mole on your skin, but since the nodules came up in a scan they want to follow up with another to be safe.  The radiologist seems to agree.  Does this sounds right?  Thank you!

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Emilie05, what I understood is that the CT scan was taken because you complaint about a back or lower abdominal pain, which was attributed to a urinary infection, and did not disappeared with medical treatment. The doctors also told you they didn't find anything that would cause you pain. So what they found on the CT scan is called "incidental finding"; it is very common to find minor, "incidental" structures on CT scans. Is called "incidental" when someone goes to the doctor for another reason and they find something else (by chance), that was not bothering.  On screening CT exams, the following types of incidental findings are common: benign nodules or masses that do not cause any symptoms, or small benign tumors that do not grow. Variations of normal anatomic structures (I can have 6 fingers in a hand but I'm not sick). Changes related to surgical operations or from old trauma (scars).  Minimal areas of scarring are not uncommon in the lung, and are often a sequela of prior infections such as pneumonia. Lung granulomas, which are small benign nodules that are caused by certain kinds of old, healed infections, are also very common, specially in the Midwestern United States, including Wisconsin. Most pulmonary nodules have benign causes. In fact, the most common lung tumor is the hamartoma, a benign one. Over 90% of suspected abnormalities seen on screening studies prove to be benign.  Small lesions in the liver are not uncommon, and are typically either simply cysts or hemangiomas. Hemangiomas are benign vascular tumors that can be seen in 10% of the population. Hemangiomas are typically in the 1-2 cm size but can be as large as 5 cm. Simple cysts are also common and are typically several millimeters to several centimeters in size and rarely grow.   Splenic lesions such as hemangiomas or cysts are also common findings. Malignant splenic tumors are rare, so small lesions in the 1-2 cms range are recognized as benign (by definition a nodule is no more than 3 cms in diameter).   At last, the worst case scenario: I find a nodule in the lung, other in the liver, and another one in the spleen; if I suspect it is cancer, I will have to assume that the primary tumor (the one that appeared first) is the lung nodule (by frequency). But, when a pulmonary nodule (3 cm or less) is found in a woman, less than 50 years old, and non-smoker, the chances of cancer are very, very little.  So I think your doctor is right.

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: This is posted, like Angela pointed out, a bit late. But just to round the previous answer, I agree with Angela, if you find a pulmonary nodule on CXR, CT or PET scan in a heavy smoker, more than age 50, there is a high propability of cancer. When there is high suspicious of cancer, and/or the nodule is not easy to reach by transthoracic needle biopsy, most thoracic surgeons prefer to go directly to open surgery. If during surgery the diagnosis of cancer is confirmed  then a lobectomy is performed and the lymph nodes in the area are removed. That is the standard procedure for Stage IA non small cell lung cancer (a tumor less than 3 cms without invasion of surrounding tissue, no lymph nodes seen on CT or PET, and no evidence of spread to other organs), which is ,apparently, the type of cancer that, maybe, your father has. If the tumor is completely removed with the lymph nodes, there is no need for radiation or chemotherapy. If complete resection of the tumor cannot be achieved or the lymph nodes are positive,  then further therapy is indicated (radiation and/or chemo).

author: Angela Grunewald, RN  Nurse Posts: 57 Joined: Sun Sep 11, 2005 12:22 am Location: USA  Contact:   Contact Angela Grunewald, RN       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: there are a couple options.......... first, you can either cough and deep breath on your own or you can use an incentive spirometer. If you cough and deep breath on your own take a nice breath in, followed by a long breath out...when you are breathing out and feel as if there is no more to give....hold your breath. this may force you to cough, otherwise just cough on your own, a nice big cough. do this as often as you would like. I would recomend every hour while you awake. This may take some time  but you will notice a difference. If you go the Incentive Spirometer route, it has the same effect however it is an actual device that allows you to measure each expiration, that way you can monitor your lung impovement. Good luck to you and Congrats for quitting. One more thing.....smoking pot has different effects on the body than smoking cigarettes. You, my friend, are saving some brain cells...good for you!...................................Angela,RN

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: kwmills, It would be hard for me to interpret your scans over the internet. The whole case should be taken into consideration. The duration between your remission and these findings is very important. The longer the duration the more in favour that this is not cancer. Your symptoms are vital. If you have recently had pneumonia then this could be a result of pneumonia. It seems that your doctor is not certain that this is indeed a recurrence which is why he sent you for a PET scan. This is good news. However, the possibility of recurrence remains and must be ruled out by every means possible. Hopefully the PET scan would clarify everything.

author: Shannon Morgan, CMA  Medical Assistant Posts: 530 Joined: Fri May 06, 2005 6:28 pm Location: Dallas, Texas. USA.
title: [no title]
content: The nodule that was in your x-ray is called a granuloma; people with past histories of pneumonia or bronchitis usually have these.  I don't have to tell you that you must stop smoking.  Welbutrin works for many people; it seems to stop the craving and reduce or eliminate withdrawl, the patch, gum, lozenges are also very helpful, but it may or may not be right for you; please see your doctor and discuss it with him.  Yes, some damage has been done, but the lungs can heal dramatically.  People who continue to smoke, even "light" cigarettes or just a few a day end up doing irreperable damage.  Better to quit now, before that happens.  Fatigue and dizziness are symptoms in too many illnesses to list; see your doctor for an evaluation.    Good luck!    Shannon

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi ninafly64, Here is some general information regarding lung cancer and hiccups. Sometimes when lung cancer is present it may metastisize (spread) to other areas of the body. In men, lung cancer may spread to the heart causing malignant pericardial effusion which causes symptoms such as shortness of breath, cough, chest pain, swelling in the upper abdomen, extreme tiredness and weakness, and hiccups. This would be one explaination for the hiccups that you may want to discuss with his physician. If an intestinal obstruction is present from disease, twist in the bowel, etc. this also causes bloating and one of the reasons for the tube down his nose into his stomach was to not only remove gastric contents but to allow the gastrintestinal tract to "rest" so the blockage or twist could resolve. Keep in mind that the hiccups alone cause bloating. Some of the medications used for hiccups are thorazine (relieves hiccups in approximately 80% of cases), reglan, valproic acid, phenobarbital, etc. If any of these medications have not been tried, you may also want to discuss this with the physician. Cancer of any type is a difficult disease not only affecting the person who has it but loved ones around them as well. My thoughts and prayers are with you and yours for grace, guidance, and understanding. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: Mesothelioma
content: Thanks for posting your question here at The Lounge.  Pleural mesothelioma (i.e.- the type that arises from the lining around the lung) can be a difficult cancer to treat.  It is often found when it is advanced.  People with the cancer usually have or do smoke cigarettes, so can have underlying lung disease (such as emphysema) that can complicate treatment.  Cisplatin and Alimta (also called pemetrexed) is one of the best regimens available to treat mesothlioma.  With that said, it does have limited benefit in that more people than not do not have their cancer respond to the treatment. The treatment does have various side effects.  Alimta needs to be given with various vitamin (i.e.- B12 and folate) supplements.  B12 and folate blood levels should be monitored since patients with low levels can have significant toxicity form Alimta.  Cisplatin itself can cause nausea, vomiting, kidney problems, hearing loss, hair loss, fatigue and decreased appetite.  As people get older, they tend to tolerate it less well than younger patients, although if someone is in good medical health otherwise, then cisplatin is usually given.  There ae not a lot of non-surgery options for treating mesothelioma.  If someone has difficulties tolerating cisplatin, then sometimes carboplatin is used since it can have less side effects than cisplatin.  However, we do not know if Alimta works as well with carboplatin as it does with cisplatin.  As mesothelioma grows, it can cause more fluid to build up even it the prior fluid problem was treated with talc powder.  Usually as the cancer grows people's health and overall condition deteriorate.  There can be worsening problems with the affected lung.  Even with treatment, mesothelioma tends to remain "under control" from the chemotherapy for a limited period of time.  Unfortunately, survival with mesothelioma tends to be measured in months, not years.  There are certain subtypes of msothelioma that behavemore aggressively than other subtypes.  I wish you Mother the best.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.

content: I am 41, and was a moderate smoker (sometimes heavy, quit for 6 years, heavy for 2, quit for 3, moderate for 2) and quit for good in January.  In 2003, I went to the doctor because of a palpable mass that was painful when pushed with fingers, right below the end of my right collar bone.  The x-ray showed nothing. I've since moved temporarily to Japan, so have not done further follow-up.   Just this weekend, it seems the pain in my right side chest is constant.  I noticed three or four yellow bruises along my pec that are sensative to touch too, and I wasn't hit or anything.  I don't typically bruise at all.  I've had physical contact with my partner, but nothing violent or aggressive that would have done that, I think.  The pain is dull, not very significant at all, but constant. I'm worried because of my past smoking, my Uncle's death from smoking lung cancer, and my mother's recent death from malenoma.  I had a basal cell carcinoma removed in 2003 from my face.  I have moles all over my body, but none in the specific areas of pain in my chest.  I'd like advice on what to tell the doctors here in Japan at a health check.  I need to have my requests given by a translator.  If this sounds like any OTHER kind of symptom, please refer me to the appropriate people.  Thanks!

author: nunnie  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Feb 26, 2005 11:24 pm Location: Montana
title: To Have a Bronchoscopy or Not?
content: Here is my question and background information.   My mother's doctor is suggesting a Bronchoscopy after being very adamant that she do nothing that would invade her lungs. More than one doctor has stated that she could NEVER go under any kind of anethesia or anything like that as she would die due to the state of her lungs.   Background:   My mother is 71 years old.   My mother had Uterine Cancer in 1960. Breast Cancer 7 years ago.   My mother has SEVERE Emphezema.   She has 33 1/2% lung capacity. This is the total of BOTH lungs.   3 years ago a spot was discovered on her lung. Small spot that did not have the characteristics of Lung Cancer.   She had a test done each year and the spot had NOT grown or changed in anyway.   1 week ago my mother had her yearly test. This was about 3 days after she just got over a bad cold or Flu which affected her lungs with a lot of coughing and phlem.   The test showed the spot had grown and appeared quite cloudy around it.   The spot STILL does NOT have the shape of Cancer according to the Lung Specialist.   The Lung Specialist said that he is "Very Concerned" about the spot. However when asked what the possibilities of it being Lung Cancer were, he stated 50/50.   She is NOT coughing up blood.   She is having NO lung or chest pain.   The Lung Specialist now says that he wants her to undergo a Bronchoscopy despite the Risks. He wishes to get a closer look in the lungs and if he feels it prudent to get a Biopsy.   He says that her Lung could collapse during the procedure. He stated "I haven't lost a patient yet". Though he did say that he wasn't real sure that the second lung could carry the load while they got the collapsed lung going again.   -------  My question is this: Do you feel that my mother should go through this?   Is it worth the risks?   Would you advise doing this type of a procedure considering the condition of her lungs at this time?   Should she wait 6 weeks, perhaps 3 months and repeat the test BEFORE undergoing the Bronchoscopy? My thinking there is that if the change in the spot was caused by some lingering affects of her cold or Flu that they may dissapear in the interim.   I might mention that she was coughing a whole lot when she was ill. However, the coughing has decreased considerably in the last week.   Do you feel that this procedure could potenially cause MORE harm than good?   The doctor stated that if it is Lung Cancer that he could NOT operate on her. His only treatment would be Chemo and Radiation.   Therefore is this procedure even necessary?   I guess basically... what I'm saying is that there seems to be a whole lot of risks with this even for a person with HEALTHY lungs. My mom is far, far from having "Healthy" lungs. It scares me to think that this procedure could actually kill her.   At this point in time, to me at least, I'm thinking that she should not do it. That she should just continue to have it checked every few weeks.   If you have any thoughts, suggestions, advise, etc on this, I sure would appreciate it. She is going to cancel her appointment for Monday. I would like to give her something to go on from another Physician to help her make her final decision.   If I have writen to the wrong section or the wrong Physician, could you please pass this on to the right person or section.   Thank you very much for your time.   I look forward to hearing from you.   PPole
posted_time: Post  by nunnie » Sat Feb 26, 2005 11:28 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi nunnie, I can only provide you with a reserved opinion since I have not actually seen your mother. Based on the information you have provided I do not think she should undergo bronchoscopy. My reasons are: lung cancers do not wait for 3 years, benign lung tumors do not turn malignant, the image results are not conclusive and if it were lung cancer the best treatment would be supportive care. Radio and chemotherapy are too hazardous and do not provide significant survival benefit. So I would assume that the best option would be to follow up after 3 months. I think you should seek the opinion of a medical oncologist. Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Sat Feb 26, 2005 11:56 pm

I felt all along that the spot could not and was not Cancer.  I had always heard that Lung Cancer is a "Quick" Cancer.  Thus your statement regarding the fact that Lung Cancers do not wait for 3 years reinforced what I had heard.  My mother asked me to express her "Thanks" to you as well.    She said that she feels she will be able to have a good nights sleep for the first time in a week.    We both now feel, Thanks to You, that our best course is to wait and have the original test redone in 3 months and NOT take the risk of the Bronchoscopy.  Thank you for providing your time to help people like us.    Smiles Across The Miles...       Nunnie - Pam Pole

author: Dr. Brim M.  Medical Doctor Posts: 16 Joined: Thu Dec 23, 2004 2:32 am Location: Birmingham, AL
title: [no title]
content: What was the indication for the original biopsy?  Was the PET scan positive in the subcarinal lymph node?  A concern would be that this is a non-PET avid tumor.  Was the histology adeno or squamous cell?  One thought (particularly if the PET wasn't positive for the biopsy positive node) would be to look for other cancer sites that could metastasize to the mediastinum such as esophageal.    If all other workup is negative, then I think mediastinoscopy is in order, with treatment directed based on how many lymph nodes are positive.

content: First let me say that I am so frustrated at this point.  I will try to explain in a timeline.  I began gaining weight approximately 1 1/2 years ago.  I have never had a problem with my weight.  I have gained 50 pounds to date and I weight 170 pounds.  I am 5' 4" tall.  The most I ever weighed was when I was pregnant and that was 140.  I have went from a six 3 to a size 16 in pants.  I have had increasing muscle weakness in mostly my left arm but now also my right.  I am extremely tired all the time.  In June of this year I woke up one day in extreme pain around my chest and back.  I went to the emergency room and they diagnosed pneumonia with pleurisy.  I had no symptoms until this day.  I took 3 courses of antibiotics and finally started to feel better, although I still have pain through my back.  I have developed a hump in my upper back and all my weight gain in in my middle section and back, and I have developed "jowls" now.  I wake up 3 or 4 times a night with night sweats.  My doctor ordered another catscan in July to follow up the June diagnosis which still showed pneumonia but this time a 3mm nodule was noted in my right lung.  A complete PFT was ordered which I didn't do so well on and carbon gases were low.  She referred me to a pulmonologist.  He ordered another catscan which was done this week.  This one shows the 3mm nodule is now 5mm and there is now another nodule on my left lung which is also 5mm.  He also said that I have fluid build up around my lungs which is what is probably causing my pain in my back.  I get very very short of breath very easily.  I have always been somewhat active.  I don't exercise on a routine but I do walk daily and I hike very frequently.  Along with climbing stairs all day etc.  I have started to have a hard time falling asleep even though I am extremely tired and the night sweats are getting worse.  I have had a couple of sharp pains through my low back and when I eat I get full very easily.  I have been coughing up blood since June, although now it is only once or twice a week.  I am so frustrated about this weight gain.  Doctor order cortisol and dhea.  Cortisol was normal but dhea was twice the normal level.  She has not ordered anything else.  I don't know what else to do.  Any advice would be appreciated.  Thank you so much in advance.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Dear Kathy0824, Although you did not mention anyone of your doctors suggesting that this may be cancer of the lung you have posted your question in this forum. Several things are important in my opinion. First the innappropriate weight gain should have been investigated earlier; second, pneumonia in an otherwise previously healthy person should not only be treated but an underlying cause should be sought. I cannot judge whether lung cancer is a clinical possiblity or not because i have not seen any of your investigations or had the chance to examine you directly. Given the information you provided here, I would want to rule out lung cancer before anything else.  Several criteria support ruling out lung cancer: 1. Family history suggests increased risk of cancer and the possibilty of hereditary types of cancer. 2. Lung nodules and unexplained pneumonia and effusion and coughing of blood could all be a manifestation of lung cancer. Especially that they are growing in size. 1. Weight gain could be a manifestation of something called paraneoplastic syndrome which could be seen in small cell lung cancer.  You are advised to seek the help of an oncologist as soon as possible. Please update your information here as we are concerned about how your condition will turn out.  Best regards,

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: "A stable 5 mm nodule in the lateral aspect of the right upper lobe. Partial resolution of the faint posterior infiltrates of both lungs which may represent atelectasis. No new infiltrates appreciated. A new 5 mm nodular density left upper lobe superior lingular segment. Partial reduction of bilateral posterior infiltrates or fibrosis compared to prior exam."   A stable (no change since previous measurements) nodule 5mm in size situated in the outer aspect of the right upper lung. Certain lesions that appear as tiny dots (infiltrates) in the back of both lungs have partially gone away, this maybe caused by lung tissue collapse (atelectesis). No new such lesions seen. A new lesion that appears to be formed of nodules is about 5mm in size and is located in the upper superior part of the lingula (a middle portion in the left lung). Partial reduction of the dotted lesions in the back of both lungs or fibrosis compared to prior exam.   This CAT scan report is more suggestive an infection than a tumor. However, I think you will benefit alot from the bronchoscopy. They will of course take a biopsy from any suspicious lesions.   Please let me know how things turn out.  Best regards,

title: Risk of minor (possible) asbestos exposure
content: With regards to asbestos-related lung cancers such as mesothelioma, how common are minor residential exposures?  I live in an older house which  contains asbestos.  I've had some ongoing water damage problems periodically which have caused minor damage, separating paint from wallboard and plaster and dripping very small amounts of water into carpeting.  This damage is very localized (less than one square foot), none of the underlying material appears to have disintigrated or become damaged, and only a very small amount (a few ounces at most) of water has drained into the carpet.  Essentially, my question is this:  Since presumably any asbestos the water picked up would become airbone when the water dries, how much asbestos exposure is cause for concern?  Obviously I'm working to correct the underlying problem, but it just dawned on me that this process is probably causing minute amount of asbestos fibers to become airborne.  All the stories I've heard about asbestos-related cancers and diseases deal with occupational exposures, but is disease relating to minor exposure as common?  Thank you very much for your time.
posted_time: Post  by AaronMH » Sat Nov 06, 2004 10:57 pm

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello AaronMH, This is a very difficult question to answer really. Occupational Safety and HealthAdministration (OSHA) has set exposure limts for thw workplace:  "Employee exposure to asbestos must not exceed 0.1 fiber per cubic centimeter (f/cc) of air, averagedover an 8-hour work shift. Short-term exposure must also be limited to not more than 1 f/cc, averaged over30 minutes. Rotation of employees to achievecompliance with either permissible exposure limit (PEL) is prohibited."  As you can see it is very difficult to apply this to the residential setting. But you can also tell from the quote above that even short term exposure can be hazardous.  I did some research on the internet for precautions to be taken when dealing with possible asbestos exposure at home and came up with this interesting link: click here!  You can also call the OSHA for more advice on this matter toll-free at this number: (800) 321-OSHA (6742).   Hope this helps.

author: AaronMH  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sat Nov 06, 2004 10:54 pm Location: TX
title: [no title]
content: Thanks for such a quick reply on a Saturday night.  One more question - when oncologists or pulmonologists diagnose a patient with an asbestos related cancer, does it generally match the patient's lifestyle as far as their past occupation/location/risk factors?  In other words, are there times where a diagnosis of asbestosis or mesothelioma comes from "out of the blue"?
posted_time: Post  by AaronMH » Sun Nov 07, 2004 1:27 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Unfortunately, yes, sometimes patients turn out to have mesothelioma and an asbestos exposure is not identified.  The diagnosis of any cancer in the lungs or pleura is suspected by signs in a chest scan and then confirmed by pathology. The risk of developing asbestos related mesothelioma or lung cancer is increased dramatically in smokers. In some, mesothelioma is diagnosed without an apparant association with asbestos.

content: Hi this is lainie again, got the results of part of my blood test, it says that my calcium level is 59 and the doctor told me that it shouldn't be higher than 37, what does that mean exactly? author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Results of Blood test
content: Dear Lainie,  i am not an oncologist but i can try to help you understand simple things.  i am not sure about your previous calcium level but a high calcium can be caused by recurrence of cancer. In cases of lung cancer, a high calcium is associated with a specific type, so if a patient has lung cancer and high calcium, the bets are high that the patient has this specific type of lung cancer. To be able to interpret the results in the context of your case, i should have previous results of your calcium levels.  Regarding pulmonary hypertrophic osteoarthropathy, this is growth of the bones around the ankles and wrist and it is present in cases of what is known as chronic toxemia, so it is not specific to cancer but can be caused by other things such as lung infection (an abscess for instance). But if found in patient, it should trigger looking for cancer as it can be caused by it. The areas affected are painful and tender on touch.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

content: I had Lung Cancer and my question is if it has traveled to another area of my body would I have a liver function test or is that for other problems ?
posted_time: Post  by lainie » Sat Aug 21, 2004 5:49 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Blood tests
content: Dear Lainie,  Yes, a blood test to detect liver abnormality resulting from cancer spread can be done but it is non-specific. It can be elevated in other cases as well.  A ultrasuond and/or a ct scan of the abdomen can be helpful as well in detecting cancer spread in the liver.  Other newer imaging techniques include a p.e.t. scan which has a very good sensitivity and specificity in detecting cancer anywhere in the body.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

content: Hello, My uncle has been having seizures for 2 years  after a few tests he has been told he has lung cancer which has gone to brain. The cancer has started moving out of lung and working down the body. He is 44 his mum passed away with exactly the same mcmillan nurses are coming in to him twice a week. doctors say he has around 6 months left but he is getting worse he is in a lot of pain and breathing is a lot worse he starts chemo and radiotherapy tomorrow can you tell me why they give chemo and radio together
posted_time: Post  by lisa j » Thu Aug 19, 2004 3:25 pm

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Lung cancer
content: Dear Lisa,   Sorry to hear about your uncle's condition.  They give chemo and radio therapies together most probably in your uncle's case as a part of palliative therapy so that he has less symptoms secondary to the cancer and its growth, but unfortunately, he will most probably experience side effects of both chemo and radio therapies as well.  He also has the choice of not receiving any treatment because i think that in your uncle's case, treatment is not going to change the outcome. So, he can choose to receive pain medications if he has pain, medications to relieve shortness of breath when he experiences that and so forth.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

content: My father, aged 53 years, had recently a CT scan. The findings are:  A.      Small lymphnodes are noted in superior mediastinum, supra carinal level (0.5-1.0cm in size) B.      Small soft tissue mass in the left lower lobe close to lower bronchus measuring 3.0 X 2.8cm likely to be neoplasm C.      Fibrotic changes associated with consolidation in lefft lower lobe. [/b]
posted_time: Post  by jukhurrum » Fri Apr 02, 2004 7:03 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Is that a case of lung cancer
content: Dear Jukhurrum,  The ct scan interpretation is consistent with a lung mass that is most probably a malignant tumour.   A biopsy is needed though to confirm the nature of this mass, if your father does not have any other signs of disseminated malignancy anywhere else (so at that time the biopsy is not needed) and he is fit enough to have it done.   Though, i am not an oncogist, if the mass proves to be malignant, i think treatment will depend on the nature of the cancer itself and whether or not it is disseminated to other organs in the body. It looks that on the ct scan, there could be an indication that there already is lymph node involvement. Your father needs a ct scan of the head and abdomen, if he has not already had them.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: What about bronchoscopy?
content: Dear Jukhurrum,  From the ct scan results, the mass is close to the lower bronchus and there is consolidation as well, so, the mass is most probably obstructing the bronchus by protruding into it or at least very close to it, so it is amenable to biopsy by using the bronchoscope, so this is a good step.  Blood tests to test are divided into  1. General:     a. Present in all types of inflammation and malignancy.     b. Examples include erythrocyte sedimentation rate and c-reactive protein. 2. Specific (also sometimes known as tumour markers):     a. Specific cancers produce specific substances in the blood.     b. Examples include psa for prostate cancer.  Regarding lung cancer, i can not really think of a specific tumour marker, but you have to put in mind that i am not an oncologist.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: Mesothelioma: Home Care Help
content: HI. My father in law has been diagnosed with Mesothelioma, and has elected to not undergo treatment of the cancer. Instead he has signed up for hospice care.  He is adminstering his own pain medication, and as of late has become much less coherent and functional. My husband is his only family member nearby.  Hospice has recommended that we get him some home care. Of course, that is very expensive. I would really like to speak to someone who can consult us on home care and ways to pay for it, etc. it was my understanding that people from hospice would be there for him if and when he needed it. Any advice?
posted_time: Post  by lizhudson78 » Mon Aug 04, 2003 5:51 pm

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: [no title]
content: Hospice care can do a lot for a patient with an end-stage disease or cancer.  It can also be a big help to the family.  Hospice is available to be of service 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.  However, Hospice is not in the patient's home all the time.  Hospice care does requirethe  family to be part of the care.  For my patients, most of the them wish to be at home and their families wish for them to be at home.  Sometimes, if the care is too much at home, a nursing or Hospice facility can be of help.  I would talk with your Father-in-law's Hospice nurse about what homecare services are covered by Hospice.  Unfortunately, not all services are covered.  It is important that your Father-in-law receive his pain medications safely.  Too little, and the pain will not be controlled.  Too much, and side effects will occur.  The Hospice program will have a good talk with you about what services your Father-in-law needs and what services he may be needing in the near future as the mesothelioma progresses.  My experience with Hospice care has been a positivie one.  It is a great help to my patients and their families.  Jeffrey A. Gordon, M.D.[/img]

author: Lanousha
title: Adenocarcinoma of the lung with brain metastasis
content: I have adenocarciona and brain metastases both were removed by surgery i do not want chemo or radiation therapy what is my life excpectancy?
posted_time: Post  by Lanousha » Sun Jan 05, 2003 11:07 am

author: JGordonMD
title: Re:
content: Lanousha,   I have read your post about your lung cancer. Could you provide more information? How many lesions in the brain were removed? Were they all removed? What is the status of your lung cancer outside of the brain? Is is growing or not?   Standard treatment of brain metastases from the lung is to seriously consider neurosurgical resection. This cannot be done all of the time. If the lesions are too large, if they are in delicate areas of the brain that surgery might cause permanent brain dysfunction, or if the lesions are too multiple in number, then surgery cannot be done. If a lesion is removed, then whole brain radiotherapy is given. A recent study presented at a national Radiation Oncology meeting has shown that using stereotactic radiosurgery after whole brain radiotherapy can be of even better benefit than using just whole brain radiotherapy alone, in select situations. The concern about just doing surgery without any follow-up radiotherapy is that any microscopic disease near where the surgery was done will grow and that further surgeries cannot be done, and that other areas of the brain may harbor microscopic disease and these areas can grow. As cancer grows in the brain, neurologic problems can develop. My best to you.
posted_time: Post  by JGordonMD » Sun Jan 05, 2003 11:08 am
